original: Lindström, Erik Lechard, lektor, Uddevalla, f. 2/7/91 i Gbg av Carl L. 0. Ohvia Petersson. G. 25 m. Ingeborg Ahlmann. Barn: Inga f. 26, Hans 29. — Stud:ex. v. Gbgs h. latin 11, fil. kand. i Gbg 14, fil. mag. 16, fil. lic. 23 o. fil. dr 25, provår v. Gbgs h. real 26. Doc. i Htt:hist. v. Gbgs högsk. 25-35. Lär. v. olika priv. läroanst. fr. 18, _vik. adj. v. Skara h. a. 1. 21-22, e. lär. v. Gbgs h. latin 27-29, lektor i modersm. o. tyska v. Uddevalla h. a. 1. sed. 29. Gbgs högsk. ■stud:kårs v. ordf. 17-18 o. 23, förlikn :man i arb:-tvister i västra distr. 3i6-44, litt :chef f. Bokförl. Hermes sed. 46. Stud:resa t. Engl. 23. Skr.: Strindbergs Mäster Olof-dramer (21), Walter Scott o. den hist. rom. o. nov. i Sv:e (grad:avh. 25), Charles Dickens (30), Nord. folk-hvsskildr. (32), art. o. rec. Medutg. av Vår litt. o. dess hist. I-IV. RNO, LVVS. .
translated: Lindström, Erik Lechard, lecturer, Uddevalla, born on 2/7/91 in Gothenburg, son of Carl L. O. Ohvia Petersson. Married on 25 with Ingeborg Ahlmann. Children: Inga born in 26, Hans in 29. — Studied at Gothenburg's high school Latin program, graduated in 11, obtained a Bachelor of Arts degree in Gothenburg in 14, Master of Arts in 16, Licentiate of Philosophy in 23 and Doctor of Philosophy in 25, had a probationary year at Gothenburg's high school in the science program in 26. Taught at various private educational institutions from 18, substitute teacher at Skara high school in 21-22, assistant teacher at Gothenburg's high school Latin program in 27-29, lecturer in Swedish and German at Uddevalla high school from 29. Gothenburg's high school student union vice chairman in 17-18 and 23, mediator in labor disputes in the western district in 31-44, literary chief for Hermes publishing house from 46. Studied or traveled to England in 23. Writings: Strindberg's play "Master Olof" (21), Walter Scott and historical novels and short stories in Swedish (degree dissertation in 25), Charles Dickens (30), Scandinavian folk literature (32), articles and reviews. Co-editor of "Our Literature and Its History" volumes I-IV. Member of the Royal Swedish Academy, Swedish Society of Letters, and History of Literature Society.

structured.name: Erik Lechard Lindström
structured.description: Erik Lechard Lindström was a Swedish lecturer born on July 2, 1891, in Gothenburg. He was the son of Carl L. O. Ohvia Petersson. He married Ingeborg Ahlmann on September 25. They had two children named Inga and Hans, born in 1926 and 1929 respectively. Lindström's educational journey included studying at Gothenburg's high school Latin program, graduating in 1911, obtaining a Bachelor's degree in Gothenburg in 1914, a Master's degree in 1916, a Licentiate of Philosophy in 1923, and a Doctorate of Philosophy in 1925. He also underwent a probationary year at Gothenburg's high school in the science program in 1926. Lindström had a teaching career at various private educational institutions starting from 1918. He worked as a substitute teacher at Skara High School from 1921 to 1922. From 1927 to 1929, he served as an assistant teacher at Gothenburg's high school Latin program. Since 1929, he held the position of a lecturer in Swedish and German at Uddevalla High School. In addition to his teaching career, Lindström had various other roles such as being the vice chairman of Gothenburg's high school student union in 1917-1918 and 1923, a mediator in labor disputes in the western district from 1931 to 1944, and the literary chief for Hermes publishing house since 1946. He traveled to England in 1923. Lindström authored several works including a play titled "Master Olof" (1921), writings on Walter Scott and historical novels and short stories in Swedish (degree dissertation in 1925), a book on Charles Dickens (1930), a book on Scandinavian folk literature (1932), as well as numerous articles and reviews. He co-edited volumes I-IV of the publication "Our Literature and Its History." Lindström was a member of the Royal Swedish Academy, the Swedish Society of Letters, and the History of Literature Society. For more information, visit the webpage dedicated to Erik Lechard Lindström.
